front.title: OpenID CAEP Event Types 1.0
front.workgroup: Shared Signals and Events Working Group

abstract.t: This document defines the CAEP Event Types. Event Types are introduced and defined in Security Event Token (SET).

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This specification is based on SSE Profile and uses the subject identifiers defined there.

section.title: Notational Conventions
section.t:
The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14
when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Event Types
section.t: The base URI for CAEP event types is: https://schemas.openid.net/secevent/caep/event-type/

section.title: Session Revoked
section.t: Session Revoked signals that the session identified by the subject has been revoked. The actual reason why the session was revoked might be specified with the nested reason_admin and/or reason_user attributes described below.

list.t: REQUIRED, the time at which the session revocation occured. Its value is a JSON number representing the number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z as measured in UTC until the date/time. This value must be less than or equal to the “iat” claim in the parent Security Event Token (SET).

OPTIONAL, describes the entity that invoked the session revocation. Potential options:
an administrator revoked the session
the end-user revoked the session
a policy evaluation resulted in the session revocation
a system or platform assertion resulted in the session revocation
OPTIONAL, an administrative message for logging and auditing
OPTIONAL, a user-friendly message for display to an end-user
OPTIONAL, tenant

section.title: Token Claims Change
section.t: Token Claims Change signals that a claim in a token specified in the subject has changed.

list.t: REQUIRED, the time at which the token claims change occured. Its value is a JSON number representing the number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z as measured in UTC until the date/time. This value must be less than or equal to the “iat” claim in the parent Security Event Token (SET).
REQUIRED, JSON object containing new uor updated claims

OPTIONAL, describes the entity that invoked the token claims change. Potential options:
an administrator revoked the session
the end-user revoked the session
a policy evaluation resulted in the token claims change
a system or platform assertion resulted in the token claims change
OPTIONAL, an administrative message for logging and auditing
OPTIONAL, a user-friendly message for display to an end-user

section.title: Credential Change
section.t:
The Credential Change event signals that a credential was created, changed, revoked or deleted. This event type can be generated for events including the following:
password/PIN change/reset certificate enrollment, renewal, revocation and deletion second factor / passwordless credential enrollment and deletion (U2F, FIDO2, OTP, app-based)

list.t: REQUIRED, the time at which the credential change occured. Its value is a JSON number representing the number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z as measured in UTC until the date/time. This value must be less than or equal to the “iat” claim in the parent Security Event Token (SET).

REQUIRED, Potential options:
password pin x509 fido2-platform fido2-roaming fido-u2f verifiable-credential sms-otp app nist-aal1 nist-aal2 nist-aal3 <other mutually supported credential type>

REQUIRED, Potential options:
create revoke update delete

OPTIONAL, describes the entity that invoked the credential change. Potential options:
an administrator revoked the session
the end-user revoked the session
a policy evaluation resulted in the credential change
a system or platform assertion resulted in the credential change
OPTIONAL, an administrative message for logging and auditing
OPTIONAL, a user-friendly message for display to an end-user
OPTIONAL, tenant
OPTIONAL, credential friendly name
OPTIONAL, the issuer of the X.509 certificate as defined in
OPTIONAL, the serial number of the X.509 certificate as defined in
OPTIONAL, FIDO2 Authenticator Attestation GUID as defined in

section.title: Device Compliance Change
section.t: Device Compliance Change signals that a device’s compliance status has changed. The actual reason why the compliance status changed might be specified with the nested reason_admin and/or reason_user attributes described below.

list.t: REQUIRED, the time at which the device compliance change occured. Its value is a JSON number representing the number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z as measured in UTC until the date/time. This value must be less than or equal to the “iat” claim in the parent Security Event Token (SET).

REQUIRED, Options:
compliant not-compliant

OPTIONAL, describes the entity that invoked the session revocation. Potential options:
an administrative action resulted in a status change
an end-user action resulted in a status change
a policy evaluation resulted in a status change
a system or platform assertion resulted in a status change
OPTIONAL, an administrative message for logging and auditing
OPTIONAL, a user-friendly message for display to an end-user
OPTIONAL, tenant

section.title: Assurance Level Change
section.t: Assurance Level Change signals that the level of assurance has changed for the subject. The actual reason for the assurance level changed might be specified with the nested reason_admin and/or reason_user attributes described below.

list.t: REQUIRED, the time at which the assurance level change occured. Its value is a JSON number representing the number of seconds from 1970-01-01T0:0:0Z as measured in UTC until the date/time. This value must be less than or equal to the “iat” claim in the parent Security Event Token (SET).

front.title: The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) Data Interchange Format

abstract.t: JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) is a lightweight, text-based, language-independent data interchange format. It was derived from the ECMAScript Programming Language Standard. JSON defines a small set of formatting rules for the portable representation of structured data.
This document removes inconsistencies with other specifications of JSON, repairs specification errors, and offers experience-based interoperability guidance.

front.title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

abstract.t: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.

front.title: Ambiguity of Uppercase vs Lowercase in RFC 2119 Key Words

abstract.t: RFC 2119 specifies common key words that may be used in protocol specifications. This document aims to reduce the ambiguity by clarifying that only UPPERCASE usage of the key words have the defined special meanings.
